Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Grant: An Ethnography of Chronic Disease Risk and Pre-Diabetes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how risk is made into an object of biomedical intervention. It will explore how biomedical risk practices and discourses are transforming contemporary social life. To illuminate these processes, the investigators will study the phenomenon of pre-diabetes in an urban environment. Pre-diabetes is a new and rapidly expanding diagnostic category. The use of the term speaks to new methods of surveillance and management of glucose in the bloodstream. It is creating a wide and growing at risk population that is situated between ill and healthy. The project will explore discourses of risk and the imperative of risk avoidance. It will be of interest to clinicians, physicians, patients, family members and health care policy makers.

The ?pre-diabetes? diagnosis is becoming a marker of individual health-status that is also emerging, alongside type 2 diabetes, as a symbol of national crisis. To analyze the pre-diabetes diagnosis in this context, the investigators will undertake 12 months of ethnographic fieldwork in an urban community. The project will be guided by four research questions: (1) How has pre-diabetes been produced, contested, and consolidated as a formal diagnostic category? (2) How is pre-diabetes communicated, understood, and acted upon both by clinicians and the individuals who receive this prediagnosis? (3) How is the specter of the pre-diabetic population mobilized political and cultural arenas? and (4) How does the case of pre-diabetes advance our understanding of risk as a social phenomenon? To answer these questions the investigators will conduct interviews with diabetes experts, healthcare providers, government and health system officials, health activists, and patients and their families. In addition it will conduct extended participant observation in three primary care clinics, in an educational program directed at pre-diabetics, and at scientific conferences. Findings will contribute to scholarship addressing the rise of preventive medicine, the associated surveillance of biomarkers, and the conversion of risk states into diagnostic categories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In middle-income countries globally, officials are working to re-shape their nation’s healthcare systems from a curative to a preventive model of care as chronic illness has supplanted the threat of infectious disease. This doctoral dissertation improvement grant supported 12 months of ethnographic fieldwork to investigate the social dimensions of efforts to implement preventive healthcare and to assess the implications of increased attention to individuals who are not yet sick but are “at risk” of developing disease.    

In dialogue with theory from the fields of science and technology studies (STS) and the sociology of medicine, this project focused specifically on interest across Mexico’s healthcare system in detecting and treating prediabetes. Prediabetes is a diagnosis assigned to individuals deemed at high risk of developing diabetes because they have elevated blood glucose levels that are above normal but not high enough to be type 2 diabetes.  While its diagnosis is increasingly common in urban Mexico, the boundaries and ideal measurement of prediabetes remain contested and subject to revision internationally, and the diagnosis is resisted by some physicians and other medical personnel. Set against Mexico’s diabetes epidemic, this project investigated the circumstances under which public health officials have, nonetheless, come to view prediabetes as worthy of diagnosis and it examined the implications in this setting of treating this pre-disease. 

During the project period, 100% of the proposed activities were completed, including 9 months of clinic-based observation across Mexico’s healthcare system, 94 in-depth interviews with patients and families, medical personnel, public officials, activists, and international experts, and an extensive review of scientific, government and media reports. Additionally, observation was conducted at 6 scientific meetings and at over a dozen activist events and community health fairs during the study period. 

Importantly, this fieldwork also constituted a period of intensive training in the use of ethnographic methods for social analysis for the co-principal investigator, who is a doctoral student and who intends to pursue a career in social science research and teach at the undergraduate and graduate levels. This one-on-one training was carried out during the study period through mentoring provided by the principal investigator via Skype meetings.    

Preliminary findings that resulted from this fieldwork were presented by the co-principal investigator in an application for an ACLS/Mellon Dissertation Completion Fellowship. The application was successful and the co-principal investigator was awarded funding to support continued data analysis and writing of the dissertation from June 2018 to May 2019. The primary outcome of the doctoral dissertation improvement grant will ultimately be the completion of the dissertation, which is expected by August 2019. 

Although analysis is ongoing and will continue through the defense of the dissertation, preliminarily findings suggest that the research funded by this doctoral dissertation improvement grant will contribute to theory in the fields of STS and the sociology of medicine across at least three domains. (1) First, while social scientists have previously examined the rise of preventive medicine and the increasing availability of knowledge about biomedical risk, their analyses have largely been limited to Western settings and primarily have pointed to increasing individual responsibilization as an outcome of these transformations. Through the case of prediabetes in Mexico, this project focuses instead on the macro-political dimensions of these transformations, analyzing the roles of the state and other powerful agents of change in public health who are mobilizing resources to identify and treat individuals who  are at risk of disease. (2) Second, this project contributes new understanding of pre-diagnoses by studying the implications of prediabetes across socio-economic status in a middle-income country, showing how this experience is stratified according to social class. (3) Third, this project has found that information about diabetes risk and the drivers of diabetes among Mexicans is entangled with historically powerful ideas about a biologically unique Mexican Mestizo body. By exploring patients’ interpretations of these messages, the project also contributes rare, ethnographically-grounded findings to STS scholarship examining the intersection of race and biomedical science in Latin America. 

Early findings from this fieldwork have been accepted for publication in 2018 in a peer-reviewed journal article and in a book chapter. Following the defense of the doctoral dissertation, the co-principal investigator will develop a book proposal based on the dissertation and seek publication of the project’s findings in peer-reviewed journals in the fields of STS and sociology. 

Additionally, as little practice-oriented qualitative research on the lived experience of prediabetes has been published from middle-income country contexts, the co-principal investigator will prepare a journal article intended for the medical and public health communities about the social and ethical implications of prediabetes diagnosis in the Mexican context. Preliminary findings were shared in early 2018 with health care providers in an oral presentation and two additional presentations are scheduled to disseminate findings to the Mexican medical and public health communities in late 2018.
